column2: Spanish: [baʎaðoˈlið] (listen)) is a city in Spain and the capital of the autonomous community of Castile and León. It has a population of 309
column3: 714 people (2013 est.)
column4: making it Spain's 13th most populous municipality and northwestern Spain's biggest city. Its metropolitan area ranks 20th in Spain with a population of 414
column5: 244 people in 23 municipalities.

column1: The city is situated at the confluence of the Pisuerga and Esgueva rivers 15 km (9.3 mi) before they join the Duero
column2: and located within five winegrowing regions: Ribera del Duero
column3: Rueda
column4: Toro
column5: Tierra de León
column6: and Cigales.

column1: Valladolid was originally settled in pre-Roman times by the Celtic Vaccaei people
column2: and later the Romans themselves. It remained a small settlement until being re-established by King Alfonso VI of Castile as a Lordship for the Count Pedro Ansúrez in 1072. It grew to prominence in the Middle Ages as the seat of the Court of Castile and being endowed with fairs and different institutions as a collegiate church
column3: University (1241)
column4: Royal Court and Chancery and the Royal Mint. The city was briefly the capital of Habsburg Spain under Phillip III between 1601 and 1606
column5: before returning indefinitely to Madrid. The city then declined until the arrival of the railway in the 19th century
column6: and with its industrialisation into the 20th century.

column1: The old town is made up of a variety of historic houses
column2: palaces
column3: churches
column4: plazas
column5: avenues and parks
column6: and includes the National Museum of Sculpture
column7: the Museum of Contemporary Art Patio Herreriano or the Oriental Museum
column8: as well as the houses of Zorrilla and Cervantes which are open as museums. Among the events that are held each year in the city are the famous Holy Week
column10: and the Festival of Theatre and Street Arts (TAC).

column1: There is no direct evidence for the origin of the modern name of Valladolid.
It is mentioned as Valledolit in the Primera Crónica General; earlier documented variants include Valledolidi
column2: Valleolide (1092) and Valleolit
column3: Valleoleti
column4: Valleoliti (1095).One widely held etymological theory suggests that the modern name Valladolid derives from the Celtiberian language expression Vallis Tolitum
column5: meaning "valley of waters"
column6: referring to the confluence of rivers in the area. Another theory suggests that the name derives from the Arabic expression (Arabic: بلد الوليد‎
column9: referring to Al-Walid I. Yet a third claims that it derives from Vallis Olivetum
column11: no olive trees are found in that terrain. Instead
column12: in the south part of the city exist an innumerable amount of pine trees. The gastronomy reflects the importance of the piñon (pine nut) as a local product
column13: not olives. In texts from the middle ages the town is called Vallisoletum
column15: and a person from the town is a Vallisoletano (male)

column1: The city is also popularly called Pucela
column2: a nickname whose origin is not clear
column3: but may refer to knights in the service of Joan of Arc
column4: known as La Pucelle. Another theory is that Pucela comes from the fact that Pozzolana cement was sold there
column5: the only city in Spain that sold it.

column1: Valladolid is located at roughly 735 metres above sea level
column2: at the centre of the Meseta Norte
column3: the plateau drained by the Douro river basin covering a major part of the Northwest of the Iberian Peninsula. The primitive urban core was built ex novo in the 11th century on a small elevation near the confluence of the Esgueva with the Pisuerga
column4: on the left-bank of the later river. The city of Valladolid currently lies on both banks of the Pisuerga
column5: a major right-bank tributary of the Douro.

column1: The city of Valladolid experiences a hot-summer Mediterranean climate (Csa) with influences of a cold semi-arid climate (BSk). Valladolid's climate features cool and windy winters due to altitude and an inland location. Fog is very typical in the morning during Winter. Winters experience snow and low temperatures below freezing during cold fronts. Valladolid's climate is influenced by the distance from the sea and its higher altitude.
Valladolid is drier than Spain's northern coastal regions
column2: although there is year-round precipitation. Average annual precipitation is 435 mm (17
column3: 12 in) and the average annual relative humidity is 65%. In winter
column4: temperatures very often (almost every second day) drop below freezing
column5: often reaching temperatures as low as −8 °C or 17.6 °F
column6: and snowfall is common
column7: while the summer months see average high temperatures of 30 °C or 86 °F. The lowest recorded temperature in Valladolid was −18.8 °C or −1.8 °F and the hottest 40.2 °C or 104.36 °F on 19 July 1995.

column1: The Vaccaei were a Celtic tribe
column2: the first people with stable presence on the sector of the middle valley of the River Duero documented in historical times.

column1: Remains of Celtiberian and of a Roman camp have been excavated near the city. The nucleus of the city was originally located in the area of the current San Miguel y el Rosarillo square and was surrounded by a palisade. Archaeological proofs of the existence of three ancient lines of walls have been found.
During the time of Muslim rule in Spain
column2: the Christian kings moved the population of this region north into more easily defended areas and deliberately created a no man's land as a buffer zone against further Moorish conquests. The area was captured from the Moors in the 10th century.

column1: In 1072 Alfonso VI of León and Castile gifted the Lordship of Valladolid to Count Pedro Ansúrez. Entrusted with the repopulation of the area
column2: Ansúrez led the foundation of the city along his wife Eylo Alfónsez. By 1084 the project for the foundation of the city was already underway. Ansúrez built a palace (now lost) and La Antigua church. Eylo founded three hospitals and the Churches of San Sebastián and San Nicolás. Both co-founded the church of Santa María. Valladolid was repopulated by people from the lands of Carrión and Saldaña.In the 12th and 13th centuries
column3: Valladolid grew rapidly
column4: favoured by the commercial privileges granted by the kings Alfonso VIII and Alfonso X.

column2: Queen Isabella I of Castile and King Ferdinand of Aragon were married in the city; by the 15th century Valladolid was the residence of the kings of Castile. In 1506
column3: Christopher Columbus died in Valladolid "still convinced that he had reached the Indies" in a house that is now a museum dedicated to him.

column2: Joanna of Austria
column3: sister of Philip II
column4: served as regent
column5: establishing herself in Valladolid
column6: with the latter becoming the political center of the Hispanic Monarchy by that time. She favoured the Ebolist Party
column7: one of the two leading factions of the Court of Philip II
column8: in competition with the albistas. The Reformation took some hold in the city appearing some Protestant circles presumably around the leading figure of Augustino de Cazalla
column9: an adviser of Joanna. Ensuing autos de fe against the Protestant sects took place in 1559 in Valladolid. A catastrophic fire in 1561 destroyed a portion of the city.During a period of 1550-1551 the town hold the first moral debate in European history to discuss the rights and treatment of the indigenous people by conquerors. See Valladolid debate.

column1: Valladolid was granted the status of city in 1596
column2: also becoming a bishopric seat.In the midst of the reign of by Philip III
column3: Valladolid briefly served as the capital of the Hispanic Monarchy between 1601 and 1606 under the auspice of the Duke of Lerma
column4: valido of Philip III. Lerma and his network had bought plots in Valladolid before in order to sell those to the Crown. Promoted by Lerma
column5: the decision on moving the capital from Madrid to Valladolid has been portrayed as case of a (double) real estate speculative scheme
column6: as Lerma had proceeded to buy housing in Madrid once the capital was moved from the city as the prices had plummeted. After a plague epidemics in Valladolid
column7: Lerma suggested the King to go back to Madrid
column8: earning a hefty profit when the Royal Court went back to Madrid and the prizes went up again accordingly.The city was again damaged by a flood of the rivers Pisuerga and Esgueva.

column1: From 1950 onwards Valladolid became an important industrial centre. This was the context in which companies such as ENDASA (1950)
column2: FASA (1954)
column3: TECNAUTO (1956) and SAVA (1957) were created. The city was declared as a Polo de Desarrollo Industrial ("Pole for Industrial Development") in 1964. During the 1960 and early 1970s the city attracted many immigrants
column4: chiefly coming from the province of Valladolid and neighbouring provinces. The city started to expand across the western bank of the Pisuerga in the early 1960s.In the context of the fraught process for the creation of the autonomous community of Castile and León (completed in 1983)
column5: Valladolid vied for the condition of regional capital
column6: competing with other cities
column7: most notably creating a sense of antagonism with Burgos. Although the capital was not explicitly enshrined in the region's statute of autonomy from 1983
column8: Valladolid was designated in 1987 as the de jure seat of the executive and legislative institutions (the Junta of Castile and León and the Cortes of Castile and León).

column2: the basic local administrative division in Spain. The Ayuntamiento de Valladolid is the body charged with the municipal government and administration. The Plenary of the ayuntamiento is formed by 27 elected municipal councillors
column3: who in turn invest the mayor. The last municipal election took place on 26 May 2019. Since 2015
column4: Óscar Puente (PSOE) serves as Mayor. He renewed his spell for a second mandate following the 2019 election.

column1: Education management and policing in Valladolid depends on the Ministry of Education of the Government of Castile and León
column2: the department responsible for the education at the regional level
column3: both at the university and non-university level.

column1: The University of Valladolid (UVA) was founded in 1241 by Alfonso VIII of Castille. It is one of the oldest universities in the world. It has four campuses around the city (Huerta del Rey
column2: Centro
column3: Río Esgueva and Miguel Delibes) as well as another three campuses scattered around the wider region of Castile and León (Palencia
column4: Soria and Segovia). Spread over 25 colleges and their associated centers
column5: about 2000 teachers give classes to more than 23
column6: 800 students enrolled in 2011.

column2: a number of administrative buildings such as the Palacio de Santa Cruz
column3: where the rector
column4: and the Museum of the University of Valladolid (MUVa)
column5: The House of Students
column6: featuring the other administrative services mainly related to international relations
column8: both located in the basement of the University Residence Alfonso VIII
column9: next to the old Faculty of Science.

column1: The Miguel de Cervantes European University (Universidad Europea Miguel de Cervantes; UEMC) is a private university with roughly 1
column2: 500 students. It is spread over three faculties: Social Sciences
column3: Law and Economics
column4: Health and the Polytechnic School. It has later expanded its campus with a new facility doubling the area devoted to teaching and research. It also has a dental clinic and a library.

column1: Lycée Français de Castilla y León
column2: a French international school
column3: is near Valladolid
column4: in Laguna de Duero.San Juán Bautista de La Salle School
column5: a High Private College in Valladolid. Integral and Superior Education. Integrates Kindergarten
column6: Primary School and High School.

column1: 12th century romanesque architecture is present in the belltowers of the churches of Santa María La Antigua and San Martín.The School of San Gregorio has been highlighted as an outstanding example Late Gothic architecture (Isabelline gothic). The Gothic style is also present in the Church of San Pablo (featuring also Renaissance and plateresque elements). The late 15th century Palace of Santa Cruz (current seat of the rectorate of the University of Valladolid) has been noted as a pioneer example of Renaissance art in Spain.

column2: considered the first in its genre in Spain
column3: was projected by Francisco de Salamanca by 1561–62
column4: following the great fire of 1561. The porticoed plaza distinctly employs stone columns with wooden footings and lintels. The design of the façades of the plaza served as template for a number of buildings in nearby streets.The unfinished Cathedral of Valladolid
column5: initially projected by Juan de Herrera in the 16th century (intending to follow a Mannerist style) experienced protracted building works owing to financial problems and its main body was not opened until 1668. Decades later
column7: Alberto de Churriguera finished the work on the main front.

column1: The Teatro Lope de Vega is a theater built in the classical style in 1861 and now very run-down. There has been recent controversy over whether the city should pay to restore it. The Campo Grande
column2: a large public park located in the heart of the city
column3: dates back to 1787. Architect Modesto Coloma Palenzuela left a key imprint in the city's outline
column4: authoring many housing projects in the late 19th to early 20th century
column5: with a good number of his buildings still standing. Standout examples of Eclectic architecture from the late 19th and early 20th century in the city include the neoplateresque City Hall
column6: the cavalry academy and Palace of Correos y Telégrafos (defaced in a revamp undergone in the 1960s) and the neobaroque new building for the university.The Francoist dictatorship left an example of "Imperial Architecture" of neo-herrerian (or escurialense) style in the building for the Seminario Menor
column7: clearly influenced by the Spanish capital's Ministry of the Air.The city preserves the residences of iconic city neighbors such as the Casa de Cervantes
column8: the Christopher Columbus House-Museum and the house of José Zorrilla.

column1: After the new neighbourhoods developed in recent decades (one example would be Covaresa) the high prices in the municipality led young people to buy properties in towns around the city
column2: so the population has tended to fall in Valladolid but is growing fast in the rest of the urban area (for example
column3: Arroyo de la Encomienda or Zaratán)

column1: Valladolid is a major economic center in Spain. The automotive industry is one of the major motors of the city's economy since the founding of FASA-Renault in 1953 for the assembling of Renault-branded vehicles
column2: which would later become Renault España. Four years later
column4: Sava was founded and started producing commercial vehicles. Sava would later be absorbed by Pegaso and since 1990 by the Italian truck manufacturer Iveco. Together with the French tire manufacturer Michelin
column5: Renault and Iveco form the most important industrial companies of the city.

column1: Besides the automotive and automotive auxiliary industries
column2: other important industrial sectors are food processing (with local companies like Acor and Queserías Entrepinares and facilities of multinationals like Cadbury
column3: Lactalis or Lesaffre)
column4: metallurgy (Lingotes Especiales
column5: Saeta die Casting...)
column6: chemical and printing. In total 22 013 people were employed in 2007 in industrial workplaces
column7: representing 14.0% of total workers.The main economic sector of Valladolid in terms of employment is however the service sector
column10: representing 74.2% of Valladolid workers affiliated to Social Security.

column2: 493 people in 2007
column3: representing 10.3% of total workers.

column1: Urban transit system was based on the Valladolid tram network from 1881 to 1933. A public urban bus system started in 1928
column2: managed by different private tenders until 1982
column3: when the service was taken over by the municipality. Today the public company AUVASA operates the network
column4: with 22 regular lines and 5 late night lines.

column1: Valladolid-Campo Grande railway station is integrated into the Spanish high-speed network AVE. The Madrid–Valladolid high-speed rail line was inaugurated on 22 December 2007. The line links both cities
column2: crossing the Sierra de Guadarrama through the namesake tunnel
column3: the fourth longest train tunnel in Europe. Valladolid will become the hub for all AVE lines connecting the north and north-west of Spain with the rest of the country. Trainsets used on this line include S-114 (max speed 250 km/h (155 mph))
column4: S-130 (Patito
column5: max speed 250 km/h (155 mph)) and the S102 (Pato
column6: max speed 320 km/h or 199 mph). This line connects the city with Madrid
column7: which can be reached in 56 minutes.

column1: Several highways connect the city to the rest of the country.
The airport serving the city is not located within the municipal limits
column2: but in Villanubla. The airport has connections to Barcelona
column3: Málaga
column4: and the Canary Islands.

column2: fish is commonly consumed
column3: some brought from the Cantabrian Sea. Fish like red bream and hake are a major part of Valladolid's cuisine.

column1: The main speciality of Valladolid is
column2: however
column3: lechazo (suckling baby lamb). The lechazo is slowly roasted in a wood oven and served with salad.

column1: Valladolid also offers a great assortment of wild mushrooms. Asparagus
column2: endive and beans can also be found. Some legumes
column3: like white beans and lentils are particularly good. Pine nuts are also produced in great quantities.

column1: Sheep cheese from Villalón de Campos
column2: the famous pata de mulo (mule's foot) is usually unripened (fresh)
column3: but if it is cured the ripening process brings out such flavour that it can compete with the best sheep cheeses in Spain.

column1: Valladolid has a bread to go with every dish
column2: like the delicious cuadros from Medina del Campo
column3: the muffins
column4: the pork-scratching bread and the lechuguinos
column5: with a pattern of concentric circles that resemble a head of lettuce.

column1: The pastries and baked goods from the province of Valladolid are well-known
column2: specially St. Mary's ring-shaped pastries
column3: St. Claire's sponge cakes
column4: pine nut balls and cream fritters.

column1: Valladolid is also a producer of wines. The ones that fall under the Designation of Origin Cigales are very good. White wines from Rueda and red wines from Ribera del Duero are known for their quality.

Holy Week ("Semana Santa" in Spanish) holds one of the best known Catholic traditions in Valladolid. The Good Friday processions are considered an exquisite and rich display of Castilian religious sculpture. On this day
column2: in the morning
column3: members of the brotherhoods on horseback make a poetic proclamation throughout the city. The "Sermon of the Seven Words" is spoken in Plaza Mayor Square. In the afternoon
column4: thousands of people take part in the Passion Procession
column5: comprising 31 pasos (religious statues)
column6: most of which date from the 16th and 17th centuries. The last statue in the procession is the Virgen de las Angustias
column7: and her return to the church is one of the most emotional moments of the celebrations
column8: with the Salve Popular sung in her honour.

column1: Easter is one of the most spectacular and emotional fiestas in Valladolid. Religious devotion
column2: art
column3: colour and music combine in acts to commemorate the resurrection of Jesus Christ: the processions. Members of the different Easter brotherhoods
column4: dressed in their characteristic robes
column5: parade through the streets carrying religious statues (pasos) to the sound of drums and music.

column1: The city is also host to one of the foremost (and oldest) international film festivals
column2: the Semana Internacional de Cine de Valladolid (Seminci)
column3: founded in 1956. Valladolid
column4: through various loopholes in state censorship
column5: was able to present films that would otherwise have been impossible to see in Spain. An award or an enthusiastic reception from the audience and the critics meant
column6: on numerous occasions
column7: that the official state bodies gave the go-ahead to certain films which Francisco Franco's regime considered out of line with their ideology.Much the same occurred with distribution on the arts circuit at the end of the 60s: a film could be placed more easily if it had previously done well at Valladolid. Even after the death of Franco in 1975
column8: Valladolid continued to be the "testing ground" for films which had been banned. For example
column9: the premiere in Spain of Stanley Kubrick's A Clockwork Orange at the 1975 festival is still recalled as a landmark.

column1: As one of Europe's oldest festivals
column2: Valladolid has always been characterized by its willingness to take risks and to innovate in its programming. It has also been keen to critically examine each new school or movement as it has arisen
column3: whether it be German
column4: Polish
column5: Chinese
column6: Canadian or otherwise. With a genuine concern for the art of cinema
column7: for film-making and film-makers rather than the more obvious commercial or glamorous aspects of the industry
column8: the festival has built up an identity of its own – equally attractive to enthusiasts

column6: the Estadio Nuevo José Zorrilla
